discussion.content:
I think the. answer is C. There is no reason not to include an end user's PC device m a QoS trust boundary
Because the first 2 choices are talking about the End User not their PC.

@disdain 
I think they pretty much assume you know they refer to the End Users PC in the question.
I think the answer is B

comments.content:
I'm going with B also

See what happens to your call quality when a user tags traffic for his PC's bittorrent site or MMRPG with voice EF.

discussion.content:
I think B is a better choice: p.351 CLCOR reference: "Most devices, such as computers and servers, cannot mark their own packets and should not
be trusted even if they can. Cisco phones, however, can mark their own packets and can be
trusted with the QoS markings they provide."

questions.question_text: Why would we not include an end user's PC device in a QoS trust boundary?

choices.A: The end user could incorrectly tag their traffic to bypass firewalls.
choices.C: There is no reason not to include an end user's PC device in a QoS trust boundary.
choices.B: The end user may incorrectly tag their traffic to be prioritized over other network traffic.
choices.D: The end user could incorrectly tag their traffic to advertise their PC as a default gateway.

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
According to the QoS Baseline Model, drag and drop the applications from the left onto the correct Per-Hop Behavior values on the right.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
Voice → EF (Expedited Forwarding)
Interactive Video → AF41
Bulk Data → AF11
Call-Signaling → AF31/CS3
Network Management → CS2

CLCOR 350-801 Official Cert Guide, p311-312

QoS Baseline Model (11 Class)

Voice: Refers to voice only, and it is marked with EF and limited to 10 percent of link bandwidth in a strict-priority queue.

Interactive Video: Refers to voice and video, and it is marked with AF41 or sometimes as EF and limited to 13 percent of link bandwidth. 

Call Signaling: Marked with CS3 and provisioned with a minimum of 2 percent of link bandwidth.

Network Management: Marked with CS2 and provisioned as guaranteed 2 percent of link bandwidth. 

Bulk Data: Marked with AF11 and provisioned with 10 percent of link bandwidth with WRED enabled.

questions.question_text: An engineer with troubleshoots poor voice quality on multiple calls. After looking at packet captures, the engineer notices high levels of jitter. Which two areas does the engineer check to prevent jitter? (Choose two.)

choices.B: MTP is enabled on the SIP trunk to Cisco Unified Border Element.
choices.E: Voice packets are classified and marked.
choices.D: All devices use wired connections instead of wireless connections.
choices.C: Cisco UBE manages voice traffic, not data traffic.

discussion.content: The trusted boundary feature is implemented with the platform qos trust extend command

Here is the documentation of your correct answer Griswald

discussion.content: I hate questions like this one. A good engineer doesn’t need to know the exact command. Whether it is platform qos trust extend or platform qos extend trust. Some people get words and letters mixed up in their head. But they’ll have no issues in front of the CLI for something like this…

comments.content:
Actually, whoever is not CCNP does not mean to be bad cisco engineer. However certification it is just a requisite to get the best salaries, see it as a good investment in money and time =).
Of course answer is A, but I am surprised to take a Catalyst 6T as a example of access switch, I was used to see tha command "switchport priority extend trust" in for example switches 3650 hahahahahaha

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
This question is based on the document "Cisco IOS Software Configuration Guide, Release 15.0SY" Chapter 1 Cisco IP Phone Support. This is a document for a Catalyst 6500.

Selected Answer: A
To send CDP packets that configure an attached Cisco IP phone to trust tagged traffic received from
a device connected to the access port on the Cisco IP phone, do not enter the cos keyword and CoS
value.
• To send CDP packets that configure an attached Cisco IP phone to mark tagged ingress traffic
received from a device connected to the access port on the Cisco IP phone, enter the cos keyword
and CoS value (valid values are 0 through 7).

Reading more I suggest that right answer is A:
This example shows how to configure Gigabit Ethernet port 5/1 to send CDP packets that tell the
Cisco IP phone to configure its access port as trusted:
Router# configure terminal
Router(config)# interface gigabitethernet 5/1
Router(config-if)# platform qos trust extend

comments.content:
From the link you shared :

Cisco IP phone to configure its access port as trusted:
Router# configure terminal
Router(config)# interface gigabitethernet 5/1
Router(config-if)# platform qos trust extend

Thus A

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I go with B: This example shows how to configure Gigabit Ethernet port 5/1 to send CDP packets that tell the
Cisco IP phone to configure its access port as untrusted and to mark all tagged traffic received from a
device connected to the access port on the Cisco IP phone with CoS 3:
Router# configure terminal
Router(config)# interface gigabitethernet 5/1
Router(config-if)# platform qos trust extend cos 3

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/lan/catalyst6500/ios/15-5SY/config_guide/sup6T/15_5_sy_swcg_6T/voip.pdf

Selected Answer: A
"The trusted boundary feature is implemented with the platform qos trust extend command"

questions.question_text: Which configuration tells a switch port to send Cisco Discovery Protocol packets that configure an attached Cisco IP phone to trust tagged traffic that is received from a device that is connected to the access port on the Cisco IP phone?

choices.A: Router# configure terminal Router(config)# interface gigabitethernet 5/1 Router(config-if)# platform qos trust extend
choices.B: Router# configure terminal Router(config)# interface gigabitethernet 5/1 Router(config-if)# platform qos trust extend cos 3
choices.D: Router# configure terminal Router(config)# interface gigabitethernet 5/1 Router(config-if)# platform qos extend trust
choices.C: Router# configure terminal Router(config)# interface gigabitethernet 5/1 Router(config-if)# platform qos trust extend cos 5

questions.question_text: Which recommendation is the best practice for marking video and voice media in a Cisco Unified Communications network?

choices.B: Voice Cos 6 (IP Precedence 4, PHB AF41, or DSCP 24) Video Cos 5 (IP Precedence 4, PHB EF, or DSCP 34)
choices.D: Voice Cos 5 (IP Precedence 5, PHB EF, or DSCP 46) Video Cos 4 (IP Precedence 4, PHB AF41, or DSCP 34)
choices.C: Voice Cos 5 (IP Precedence 2, PHB EF, or DSCP 48) Video Cos 4 (IP Precedence 4, PHB AF41, or DSCP 46)
choices.A: Voice Cos 5 (IP Precedence 6, PHB AF41, or DSCP 16) Video Cos 4 (IP Precedence 5, PHB EF, or DSCP 32)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Voting comment for D.

CLCOR 350-801 Official Cert Guide, p 317.
Application L3 ToS/IPP PHB DSCP CoS
Voice Only 5 EF 46 5
Voice/Video 4 AF41 34 4
